awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Nutritional Landscapes of Arctic Caribou: Observations, Experiments, and Models Provide Process-Level Understanding of Forage Traits and Trajectories
awd_abstract_narration:
Terrestrial Arctic systems are the result of complex interactions between climate, vegetation, herbivores, and humans that must be studied together to understand their functional traits. While low temperatures and short-growing seasons limit plant growth, enough plant biomass exists to support herds of migratory caribou, on which Alaska Natives depend. Any changes in the plants at the base of the food web can have cascading consequences for herbivores and human consumers and their interactions. Today, the Arctic system is in the midst of change resulting in new vegetation assemblages, changes in the nutritive value of plant tissues, and ultimately in the diets of migratory caribou and the humans that depend on them. This project examines the nutritional landscape of the Central Arctic Caribou Herd as a unifying concept, describing the nutritional landscape as caribou available protein (CAP) and caribou available energy (CAE), integrative forage quantity measures that reflect biomass, species composition, plant C and N content, digestibility, and secondary compounds. The core objectives are gaining understanding of the drivers of spatial and temporal patterns in the amounts of CAP and CAE across the tundra; caribou use of this nutritional landscape; how the amounts of CAP and CAE will differ in the future under likely climate scenarios and long-term experiments, and the interactions between caribou and Native communities. 

The broader impacts of this study involve several groups of Alaskan stakeholders, including: harvesters of the North Slope community of Nuiqsut, the worldwide caribou community, and students at multiple stages of education. The project will embed a team member with hunters in Nuiqsut, and develop an educational scientific documentary on the caribou - Alaska Native interactions for high school students. The group plans to employ village students and undergraduates affiliated with the Alaska Native Science and Engineering Program to assist with experimental work and vegetation collection at Toolik Lake. This research is significant to ecologists from the Circumarctic Rangifer Monitoring and Assessment Network, dedicated to caribou conservation and sustainable management in the US, Canada, and Scandinavia, who will use the data to consider how a suite of climate change scenarios affect herd fecundity and population dynamics. 

The intellectual merit of this project stems from the merging of five elements to understand Arctic System function and response to climate change: (1) A landscape-scale assessment of plant species, soil and plant C and N, digestibility, and secondary compounds that will be used to calculate the amounts of CAP (kg m-2) and CAE (kJ m-2); (2) analysis of how closely caribou foraging is tied to the nutritional landscape throughout the year; (3) analysis of samples from an existing long-term winter - summer climate change experiment to provide data on how CAP and CAE will differ in the future; (4) prediction of future nutritional landscapes and caribou foraging interactions; and (5) observations of Alaska Native hunter harvesting and attributes of the system that determine their spatial and temporal patterns. These project components will enable an integrative understanding of how an important herbivore, caribou, interact with a landscape that is rapidly changing. This research: (1) examines the Arctic System from primary production to secondary consumers and the influence of climate change across multiple trophic levels; (2) applies broadly by examining the most abundant large herbivore and its food sources, both of which are distributed throughout the Arctic; and (3) integrates experimental, observational, and modeling approaches to understanding ecological systems and climate change. The integration of observation, experimental data and modeling to describe current and forecast future nutritional landscapes is intended to provide a mechanistic understanding of Arctic System function and transform the understanding of climate-vegetation-caribou-subsistence hunter interactions.

por.por_cntn:
Modelling tool for spring, summer and fall nutritional ecology of the Central Arctic Herd

 

Objectives: This project addresses two of the primary objectives of the NSF project: 1) landscape-scale assessment of plant nutrients of the CAH and, 2) a prediction of future nutritional landscapes and caribou foraging interactions.

Approach: We employed an Energy-protein model (White et al 2014), incorporating plant nutritional data (Neutral Detergent fibre, NDF; Acid Detergent Fibre, ADF, Nitrogen content, and Bovine Serum Albumin, BSA) collected during the NSF project, augmented by previous plant nutritional data from the CAH range (Adams et al 2018) and Seward Peninsula (Finstad 2008). To explore implications of climate change, all data was assigned a Growing Degree Day (GDD) of collection date based on CARMA?s climate database (Russell et al 2013), depending on seasonal range and physical location (coastal plain, foothills, Brooks Range). To facilitate scenarios, we developed a dynamic spreadsheet, linked to the climate database between 1980-2019, that related Nitrogen to GDD, NDF to Nitrogen, ADF to NDF and BSA to GDD. Thus, by changing key climate indicators all nutrient attributes would be updated daily for the ordinal date 140-283 period.

We explored the nutritional attributes of four major vegetation communities utilized by the CAH between late May and mid October:  Coastal wetlands, non-tussock graminoids, tussock tundra and dwarf shrub. The latest vegetation map for the region was downloaded (Reynolds et al 2019) and types were binned to best represent the four types listed above. Based on movements of 10 randomly selected collared caribou, these four types represent 97% of vegetation types used between ordinal date 140-283.

Biomass estimates of 10 plant groups for the four vegetation types were estimated from data of Walker et al (2003) and diet associated within each vegetation type was generated by an algorithm developed by White et al (1999).

Scenarios explored: We developed a number of scenarios and have produced preliminary results of key indicators from the a) Rumen sub-model (daily metabolizable energy intake (MEI), metabolizable nitrogen intake (MNI)) and b) Allocation sub-model (fall cow weight, cow fat weight, cow protein weight and fall calf weight).

Our scenarios were:

1)      forcing caribou to stay in one vegetation type throughout the simulation period (for example results if animal stayed in the wetland type from ordinal date 140-283). Comparing the results for the four vegetation types reveals the relative advantage/disadvantage of each type throughout the simulation period.

2)      Based on the results of 1) above, we asked the question: what would be the results if caribou moved throughout the simulation period to the vegetation type that yielded the highest MEI and alternatively the highest MNI.

3)      Based on 2) above what would be the implication if future species shifts resulted in Betula as the dominant deciduous shrub versus Salix.

4)      Based on results of Richert et al 2020, what if future snow conditions resulted in enhanced nitrogen content in key plant groups (deciduous shrubs and graminoids).

5)      Based on the results of Scenario 2 above, we explored the nutritional consequences of caribou moving back to the coast during a bad insect year (see Johnson et al 2018).

6)      The final scenarios made use of movement paths of 10 collared CAH caribou (interpolated to produce daily locations), to examine the variability in fall cow and calf weights depending solely on the frequency of vegetation types utilized.

7)      Further, using the collar movements, we conducted a comparative analysis of cool, average and warm summers on MEI, MNI and fall calf and cow weight. These runs were further used to determine implications on winter overwinter calf mortality and probability of pregnancy for the cow.

8)      Finally, we use the collar movements to explore implications of caribou interacting with development (10 days in a Zone of Influence) during: 8a) pre-calving, 8b) post-calving, 8c) insect season and 8d) late summer). Results quantify potential cost to the cow and calf in terms of timing of encounters with oil development infrastructure.

Some Preliminary results:  The model runs are still being calibrated, as new datasets are being incorporated. However, the examples below provide an indication of the results from the models to date. Figures 1-4 (attached) scenarios 1, 3, 7 and 8 listed above

 Future progress: Once calibration of models are complete, we will finalize current results and apply these results to a population dynamics model to quantify implications of summer nutritional scenarios at the population level for the Central Arctic Herd.  Goal is to have a submitted manuscript in 2022.
